user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 8.13 is: A pointer should point to a const-qualified type whenever possible.

</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of metal_linux_probe_bus:
```c
static int metal_linux_probe_bus(struct linux_bus *lbus)
{
	struct linux_driver *ldrv;
	int ret, error = -ENODEV;

	lbus->sbus = sysfs_open_bus(lbus->bus_name);
	if (!lbus->sbus)
		return -ENODEV;

	for_each_linux_driver(lbus, ldrv) {
		ret = metal_linux_probe_driver(lbus, ldrv);
		/* Clear the error if any driver is available */
		if (!ret)
			error = ret;
	}

	if (error) {
		metal_linux_bus_close(&lbus->bus);
		return error;
	}

	error = metal_linux_register_bus(lbus);
	if (error)
		metal_linux_bus_close(&lbus->bus);

	return error;
}
```
</target_code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
error = metal_linux_register_bus(lbus);
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 8.13 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: Not violated in this code: lbus is written to earlier in the function (lbus->sbus = ... and metal_linux_bus_close(&lbus->bus) uses non-const access), so lbus cannot be const-qualified and passing it to metal_linux_register_bus does not by itself violate Rule 8.13. (A violation would occur if neither this function nor metal_linux_register_bus modify the pointed-to object — in that case lbus should be declared as const struct linux_bus * and metal_linux_register_bus should accept a pointer-to-const.)
